Why every era seems to have its own heartbeat â€” and what that rhythm reveals about us

A hundred years of baseball heard, not just measured â€” where numbers whisper the story of how the game learned to breathe differently with each generation.

> *What if every statistic were a note, and a hundred years of baseball formed a song weâ€™ve only just begun to hear?* ## [ğŸ§¢]{aria-hidden="true"} The Game That Breathes Baseball isnâ€™t timed by a clock, but it still has a **tempo**. Some eras feel quick and scrappy, others patient and thunderous. In this story, weâ€™ll *listen* to that tempo using longâ€‘run league averages. If you donâ€™t speak data â€” no problem. Think of every chart as a **stethoscope** on the gameâ€™s chest. ### [ğŸ§°]{aria-hidden="true"} What data are we using? Weâ€™ll use the wellâ€‘known **Lahman** database (public, free) through R. Weâ€™ll count simple things anyone can grasp: **runs**, **home runs**, **walks**, **strikeouts**, and **stolen bases**. From these counts, we compute commonsense rates, like â€œhome runs **per plate appearance**.â€ ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) library(Lahman) # Safe rate helper rate <- function(n, d) ifelse(d > 0, n / d, NA_real_) # Build league-level season summary from Teams season <- Teams %>% transmute( year = yearID, g = G, r = R, hr = HR, bb = BB, so = SO, sb = SB, ab = AB, hbp = coalesce(HBP, 0L), sf = coalesce(SF, 0L), pa = AB + BB + hbp + sf ) %>% group_by(year) %>% summarise( g = sum(g, na.rm = TRUE), r_pg = rate(sum(r, na.rm = TRUE), g), # Use summed plate appearances; if pa has gaps early on, fall back to AB+BB pa_sum = sum(pa, na.rm = TRUE), abbb = sum(ab + bb, na.rm = TRUE), denom = ifelse(pa_sum > 0, pa_sum, abbb), hr_pa = rate(sum(hr, na.rm = TRUE), denom), bb_pa = rate(sum(bb, na.rm = TRUE), denom), so_pa = rate(sum(so, na.rm = TRUE), denom), sb_pa = rate(sum(sb, na.rm = TRUE), denom) ) %>% ungroup() %>% arrange(year) %>% mutate( # 5-year right-aligned moving average using base R (no zoo needed) rpg_roll5 = as.numeric(stats::filter(r_pg, rep(1/5, 5), sides = 1)), tto_share = hr_pa + bb_pa + so_pa, bip_share = pmax(0, 1 - tto_share) ) ``` ::: ::: callout-tip\ **Decoder** - *per PA* â‰ˆ per trip to the plate. - *Runs per game* = average runs a team scores in a game that year. - *Balls in play* = anything that isnâ€™t a HR, walk, or strikeout. ::: ## [ğŸ¼]{aria-hidden="true"} A Heartbeat You Can See: Runs Per Game If the game were breathing, **runs per game** would be its chest rising and falling. Peaks = lively offense. Valleys = pitcherâ€‘dominated eras. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} season %>% ggplot(aes(year, r_pg)) + geom_line(alpha = 0.85) + geom_line(aes(y = rpg_roll5), linewidth = 1.1) + labs( title = "Runs per Team Game over Time", subtitle = "The 5â€‘year smoother reveals gentle waves rather than a straight trend", x = NULL, y = "Runs per game" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](the-hidden-rhythm-of-baseball_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: **What to notice:** The line **waves**. Offense doesnâ€™t simply climb forever â€” it **surges and recedes** across generations. ## [ğŸ’¥]{aria-hidden="true"} Fewer Things Happen, Louder When They Do Modern baseball increasingly ends in one of three ways: **home run, walk, or strikeout**. That means fewer balls are fielded. The game can *feel* slower between bursts of action, even while the big moments are bigger. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} season %>% select(year, hr_pa, bb_pa, so_pa) %>% pivot_longer(-year, names_to = "metric", values_to = "rate" ) %>% mutate( metric = recode(metric, hr_pa = "Home runs per PA", bb_pa = "Walks per PA", so_pa = "Strikeouts per PA") ) %>% ggplot(aes(year, rate, linetype = metric)) + geom_line() + labs( title = "The Three True Outcomes over Time", subtitle = "Share per plate appearance (league average)", x = NULL, y = "Rate" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](the-hidden-rhythm-of-baseball_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: **What to notice:** Strikeouts climb steadily; home runs rise in bursts; walks bob up and down. Together they take up **more of the action pie**. ## [ğŸ§¶]{aria-hidden="true"} Thread Count: How Much Play Is *In* Play? Letâ€™s peek at the **share of balls in play** â€” the portion of plate appearances that *require* a fielder to do something. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} season %>% ggplot(aes(year, bip_share)) + geom_line() + labs( title = "Balls In Play as a Share of All Plate Appearances", subtitle = "When this falls, the game has fewer fielding plays and more allâ€‘orâ€‘nothing outcomes", x = NULL, y = "Share (0â€“1)" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](the-hidden-rhythm-of-baseball_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: **What to notice:** When this dips, the gameâ€™s rhythm changes â€” fewer sprints and throws, more waiting for the next big swing. ## [ğŸƒ]{aria-hidden="true"} Speedâ€™s Comeback Arc Steals add heartbeat. Their rise and fall shows how teams toggle between **risk** and **power**. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} season %>% ggplot(aes(year, sb_pa)) + geom_line() + labs( title = "Stolen Bases per Plate Appearance", subtitle = "Risk tolerance in motion", x = NULL, y = "SB per PA" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](the-hidden-rhythm-of-baseball_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: **What to notice:** Cycles. The sport rediscovering speed isnâ€™t nostalgia â€” itâ€™s ecology. When defenses and pitchers neutralize power, **movement** becomes valuable again. ## [ğŸŒ€]{aria-hidden="true"} A Simple â€œZeit Rhythmâ€ Index To summarize the *feel* of an era, we blend four dials: - **Power** (HR/PA) - **Miss** (SO/PA) - **Movement** (SB/PA) - **Play in the Field** (Balls in play share, but we subtract it â€” less BIP = more allâ€‘orâ€‘nothing feel) The result is a single line: higher = louder, burstier baseball; lower = more contactâ€‘heavy flow. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} zi <- season %>% mutate(across(c(hr_pa, so_pa, sb_pa, bip_share), scale)) %>% mutate(ZI = as.numeric(hr_pa + so_pa + sb_pa - bip_share)) %>% mutate(ZI_roll5 = as.numeric(stats::filter(ZI, rep(1/5, 5), sides = 1))) %>% select(year, ZI, ZI_roll5) zi %>% ggplot(aes(year, ZI)) + geom_hline(yintercept = 0, linewidth = 0.3) + geom_line(alpha = 0.55) + geom_line(aes(y = ZI_roll5), linewidth = 1.1) + labs( title = "Zeit Rhythm Index", subtitle = "A blended, zâ€‘scored feel of power + miss + movement âˆ’ balls in play", x = NULL, y = "Index (0 â‰ˆ average era)" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](the-hidden-rhythm-of-baseball_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: **What to notice:** The line **oscillates in multiâ€‘decade waves** rather than drifting randomly â€” a hint that baseball selfâ€‘corrects when any one style takes over. ## [ğŸ”­]{aria-hidden="true"} What This Suggests Next - **Contact renaissance**: As pitchers and defenses optimize for strikeouts and power prevention, putting the ball in play may regain value â€” not as nostalgia, but as an *edge*. - **Smart speed**: Selective stealing and hitâ€‘andâ€‘run tactics may return in pockets where they exploit pitcher/catcher timing. - **Fielding theater**: If leagues want more visible action, rule tweaks that increase balls in play could shift the rhythm again. ## [ğŸ“¦]{aria-hidden="true"} Reproducibility Notes - **Source**: The public **Lahman** database via the `Lahman` R package. - **Averages**: We averaged teams into a single league line per year to hear the broad rhythm (details will vary by ballpark or league). - **Approximations**: Older seasons are missing some counts (like sacrifice flies). We used simple, conservative fallbacks that donâ€™t change the big picture. - **Smoothing**: A gentle 5â€‘year average makes the waves easier to see. ## [ğŸ“š]{aria-hidden="true"} References & Credits - **Sean Lahman** â€” *Lahman Baseball Database* (public historical stats). - **Lahman (R package, CRAN)** â€” convenient access to the database. - **tidyverse (CRAN)** â€” data wrangling and plotting in R. - **zoo (CRAN)** â€” rolling averages. *Inspirations:* FanGraphs and Baseballâ€‘Reference for longstanding public analytics; the broader sabermetric community for opening up the conversation.
